Crown_of_Polish_Mountains.about_crown: The concept of the Crown of Polish Mountains was presented in 1997 by Marek Więckowski and Wojciech Lewandowski in the June issue of the magazine "Get to know our country". Initially, the list of peaks contained 27 peaks. When announcing the idea of ​​the KGP, it was not only about relieving the most popular mountains, especially the Tatras, and popularizing many other attractive but unknown ranges, but also about in-depth knowledge of these regions of the country, with their history, nature, geological past and contemporary culture.

comments.comment: Mount Rysy consists of three peaks and the highest of them is located entirely on the Slovak side (2501 m.a.s.l.) - that is why it is not included in the Crown of Polish Mountains.
This is the only mountain from this ranking for which we know the exact date of the first ascent.

Most of the mountain ranges included in the Crown are mesoregions. Meanwhile, Rysy is included as the highest peak of the Tatra Chain macroregion (and at the same time of the Eastern Tatras mesoregion), excluding the Western Tatras, the highest peak of which in Poland is Starorobociański Wierch.

peak.name: Babia Gora
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Tarnica
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: The authors of the crown in the Beskid Lesisty macroregion included only the Bieszczady mesoregion (with Tarnica), omitting its other part, the Sanocko-Turczańskie Mountains, in which the highest are Trohaniec or Jaworniki.

peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: The Bialskie Mountains are the biggest controversy of the Crown because they are actually part of the Golden Mountains, so the Bialskie Mountains should not be included in the Crown at all

peak.name: Orlica
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Wysoka
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: The Crown includes the Pieniny Mountains (with Wysoka, 1,050 m above sea level) belonging to the Orawa-Podhale Depression, excluding its second mountainous mesoregion, which is higher than the Pieniny Mountains, the Spisko-Gubałowskie Foothills (with Magura Witowska, 1,232 m above sea level).

peak.name: Wielka Sowa
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Lackowa
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Kowadlo
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: The highest peak of the entire Golden Mountains on the Polish side is Brusek or Postawna (different sources give different heights; however, there are no marked tourist trails leading to them), not Kowadło.

peak.name: Jagodna
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: The highest peak of the Bystrzyckie Mountains is not Jagodna (977 m above sea level), but a formally unnamed peak with a height of 985 m above sea level.

peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Szczeliniec Wielki
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.
peak.country: Poland Lower Silesia Table's Mountains NP

peak.name: Lubomir
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: According to the authors of Crown, the highest peak of Beskid Makowski is Lubomir, while according to the regionalization of another expert, this peak belongs to Beskid Wyspowy, and the highest peak of Beskid Makowski is Mędralowa. It is worth noting, however, that an earlier regionalization by the same author from 1977 assigns Lubomir to the Beskid Makowski Mountains.

peak.name: Biskupia Kopa
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Chelmiec
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: Chełmiec should not be included in the Crown because its measurement point was located on an 18-meter observation tower and was therefore considered the highest in the Wałbrzyskie Mountains, but in fact the highest is Borowa Mountain.

peak.name: Klodzka Gora
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: In the crown, Kłodzka Góra is listed as the highest peak of the Bardzkie Mountains, although more recent measurements have shown that Szeroka Góra, located nearby, is higher.

peak.name: Skopiec
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: According to the latest measurements, the highest peak of the Kaczawskie Mountains is Okole (725.3 m above sea level), previously considered higher, Skopiec is only 720.7 m above sea level.

peak.name: Sleza
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

peak.name: Lysica
peak.first_ascent: No information about the first conqueror. The peak has been climbed since prehistoric times.

comments.comment: Only Łysica was included in the Świętokrzyskie Mountains, despite the fact that they are divided into two main ranges.

In 2019, it was confirmed that the highest peak of the Świętokrzyskie Mountains is the eastern peak of Łysica called Agata. The latest measurements showed 613.96 m above sea level. which gives it an advantage over the latest measurements of Łysica (613.33 m above sea level).
